Sentence: Valentin tried to stop the wedding, but his (Valentin) mother, the Marquise and his (Valentin) brother, Urbain--the imposing older figure who barred Newman's first visit--coveted the Count's pedigree and fortune
Delighted by Newman's success, Valentin arranges an audience with the heads of the family--the forbidding Marquise and Urbain--later that week
When the others have left for a ball, Newman bluntly tells the Marquise that he (Newman) would like to marry her (Newman) daughter
After inquiring with equal frankness about his (Newman) wealth, the Marquise grudgingly agrees to consider his (Marquise) proposal
He (Newman) surprises first the Marquis and then Claire in heated discussions with Lord Deepmere, but thinks little of it

Bread, who tells him (Newman) the full secret--the Marquise and Urbain killed the Marquis, Claire's father, at the family's country home because he (Newman) opposed Claire's first marriage to the Comte de Cintr??
Bread gives Newman a secret testament to these circumstances that the Marquis wrote just before he (Newman) died
After the service, he (Newman) confronts the Marquise and Urbain with the details of their crime and a copy of the Marquis' letter
Realizing that Claire is completely lost to him (Newman), Newman destroys the Marquis' incriminatory note in Mrs
